li.class: mega-menu menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-has-children menu-item-4753

div.p: CORONAVIRUS - Get the latest information on COVID-19 in North Carolina.

In response to COVID-19, more commonly known as the coronavirus, many North Carolina residents are being asked to work and learn remotely. To help ensure they can access high-speed internet, we have compiled a list of new and existing free or affordable service offerings from vendors across the state.
If you are a service provider that is offering free or affordable options for high-speed internet during this time, please contact us at COVID.vendor.ideas@nc.gov.
Use the map on this page to determine if your area is covered by these providers:

ol.li: Enter your home street address in the address field and click the magnifying glass. (You can also use the location icon to the right of the magnifying glass to allow the browser to determine your location for you.)
Click on your location to see offers available to your address.

div.p: In an effort to help serve their residents, many communities and vendors around North Carolina are offering Wi-Fi access locations for public use.

Executive Order 121 issues a statewide Stay at Home Order beginning Monday, March 30, 2020 at 5 p.m. until April 29, 2020, directing people to stay at home except to visit essential businesses, to exercise outdoors or to help a family member. Specifically, the order bans gatherings of more than 10 people and directs everyone to physically stay at least six feet apart from others. Practice social distancing while using Wi-Fi access locations to the greatest extent possible. Click here for more information on COVID-19 Guidance.
Below is a list of public Wi-Fi access locations that have been reported to the Broadband Infrastructure Office. Use the map on this page to search for specific locations.
If you are a community, business or organization that is offering public Wi-Fi access locations, please send a message to COVID.vendor.ideas@nc.gov.

div.a: Click here for the full list

div.p: Below is a list of new and existing free or reduced service offerings that have been reported to the Broadband Infrastructure Office. Use the map on this page to search for specific locations.
If you are a service provider that is offering free or affordable options for high-speed internet during this time, please contact us at COVID.vendor.ideas@nc.gov.

ul.li: Free Altice Advantage 30Mbps internet service for 60 days, beginning March 16, to households that do not already have a broadband subscription and have children in grades K-12 or in college.

High speed internet will be available at a reduced price of $29.95/month for six months, to households that do not already have a broadband subscription and have children in grades K-12 or in college.
Where: Brunswick and Columbus counties
Contact: 910-754-4311, Monday- Friday, 8 a.m.- 6 p.m.

Low-cost wireline home Internet service to qualifying households:
With at least one resident who participates in the U.S. Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP), National School Lunch Program or Head Start and
With an address in AT&T’s 21-state service area, at which AT&T offer wireline home Internet service; and
Without outstanding debt for AT&T fixed Internet service within the last six months or outstanding debt incurred under this program.
Service availability and speed may vary by address. AT&T will assign you the fastest of these speed tiers available* where you live:
768 kilobits per second, for $5 per month
1.5 megabits per second, for $5 per month
3 megabits per second, for $5 per month
5 megabits per second, for $10 per month
10 megabits per second, for $10 per month**
3-months of free wireless service for frontline nurses and physicians nationwide on the FirstNet network – built with AT&T in a public-private partnership with the First Responder Network Authority
Suspending data usage limits

Offering K-12 schools, colleges, universities, libraries and state and local government agencies increased broadband speeds for free for 60 days at existing service locations with qualifying facilities
Automatically increasing broadband speeds where technically feasible for residential customers currently enrolled in plans offering 20 Mbps or less

Free high-speed internet service up to 100 Mbps for 60 days, beginning March 16, to households that do not already have a broadband subscription and have children in grades K-12 or in college. Standard installation included.
For eligible low-income households without school-aged children, Charter continues to offer Spectrum Internet Assist, a low-cost broadband program delivering speeds of 30 Mbps.
New low-income customers will receive 60 days of complimentary Internet Essentials service, normally $9.95/month (at speeds of 25 Mbps downstream and 3 Mbps upstream)

Free Standard HSI service for 60 days, beginning March 16, to households that do not already have a broadband subscription and have children in grades K-12 or in college. Standard installation included, and no security deposit required.
Limited-time, first month free of Connect2Compete service, $9.95 per month thereafter.

li.span: e and remote desktop support through Cox Complete Care
A Learn from Home toolkit for schools, including instructions on how to fast-track eligible students without internet access

ul.li: As of March 25, no disconnections for non-payment for at least 30 days
Increasing the speed of the Mediacom Connect2Compete low-cost internet program to 25 megabits per second (Mbps) down by 3 Mbps up
Pausing monthly data allowances across all Mediacom broadband service tiers through May 15, 2020
Extending the pricing of Mediacom’s Access Internet 60 broadband service to new customers at $19.99 per month for the next 12 month

60 days of free Standard Broadband service and free installation to any home that is:
The primary home of a student in kindergarten through high school, in technical school, in college or in graduate school;
Currently without our internet service and that hasn’t had internet service with SkyLine/SkyBest for the past 90 days; and
Located where SkyLine/SkyBest would normally provide internet service.
Waiving installation fees during this time

Free home internet for K-12 high school students, technical college or graduate students for 60 days
Offer expires April 3 2020

Unlimited wireless data service for qualified schools (K-12, colleges and universities) on new lines for school-issued tablets, 4G LTE-enabled laptops and hotspot devices
Offer good through May 22nd
Free integrated phone, fax, messaging capabilities and HD video conferencing for up to 100 users for new education, healthcare and non-profit social services
Free access and unlimited usage of Caribu, a video-calling application that allows family members to read, draw, and play games with one another while at different locations

$15 per month per device for 10GB of data for the public sector
No Charge on refurbished hotspots
No charge on tablets
No charge on connected Chromebooks
While supplies last
Requirement of 6 months of service
Free increased 20GB data allowance per month for 60 days, beginning March 16, for schools and students using EmpowerED digital learning programs
Unlimited plan for $20/month a two-year contract on qualifying plans
Unlimited smartphone data for 60 days, beginning March 16, for all current T-Mobile and Metro by T-Mobile customers with data plans
Additional 20GB of mobile hotspot/tethering service for 60 days, beginning March 16, for T-Mobile and Metro by T-Mobile customers.
Free international calling for all current T-Mobile and Metro by T-Mobile customers to Level 3 impacted countries.
Participating schools can receive up to $200 per student to put toward mobile internet devices, including hotspots, laptops, and tablets

li.span: to all tablets and laptops within the Verizon Innovative Learning program
Will waive overage charges and late fees to support customers who may be financially affected by the COVID-19 crisis
Adds 15GB of high-speed data for wireless consumer and small business customers to be automatically applied with no customer action necessary
Provides first responders with priority and preemption abilities for voice and data
